results.title: Gumby : a miner affair
results.brief_description: Gumby, the worlds favourite clayboy invites you to join him and his friends Pokey the Horse, Prickle the dinosaur, and Goo the Blue Mermaid as they share eight fabulous new adventures: Mirror-aculous recovery ; As the worm turns ; Lost treasure ; Beetle and the caterpillar ; A Miner affair ; All cooped up ; Wild girls ; A Smashing hit.

results.title: Gum preparation, stone flaking etc; (Episode 2) (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Ian Dunlop
results.brief_description: In 1965 and in 1967 the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies sponsored a film trip, but eh Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, to the Western Desert Region of Australia. The object of the trip was to film the daily life of nomadic Aborigines of the area. An attempt was made to locate groups still living in the desert. 63,000 feet of film were shot and in this record, or archival version of the material, every shot having ethnographic value is included. Film grammar has, in every case, taken second place. The film is divided into nineteen parts, seventeen of which were purchased for inclusion in the Film Library. Parts 3 and 11 were not purchased as they contain sacred material and , as such, are not suitable for use in schools. The seventeen parts which are in the library are more suited for used in secondary schools than in primary schools. However, titles will be recommended by Curriculum and Research Branch for use with the new Primary Social Studies Course. For general screenings, a condensed version has been made under the title of “Desert People”, catalogue number 2790. 3604. Part 1, 21 min, b&w. Seed-cake making and general camp activity. 3602. part 2, 19 min b&w. Gum preparation, stone flaking, Djagamara leave Badjar.

results.title: Gulliver in Lilliput
results.brief_description: This enthralling production, using the intricacies of colour separation overlay, captures all the magic and humour of Swift’s brilliant spoof on the follies of mankind. “Gulliver’s Travels” has been a bestseller since it was first published over 250 years ago and tells the story of Gulliver’s adventures among the tiny Lilliputians who are obsessed by petty rivalries and trivia. It is both a timeless political satire and a fascinating tale of extraordinary travels in strange lands, which can be enjoyed by both adults and children. The adaptation is tight and amusing and the special effects really are something. Rated: G

results.title: Gulfstream
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Bruce Mackay and William Hansen
results.brief_description: A beautifully photographed film that records a sailing expedition through the Gulf Stream in the North Atlantic sea. The changing weather patterns are discussed and the many species of animals, that inhabit the waters, are examined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Bruce Mackay and William Hansen

results.title: Gulf Country
results.brief_description: The country in Northern Australia bordering on the Gulf of Carpentaria is a flat, dry area in which the rivers and creeks seldom run and isolated water holes keep the wild life and stock alive. At the time when gold was being mined there several townships were flourishing but these are largely abandoned. The Mitchell River Mission looks after aborigines of the district who are free to come and go as they please, and some are employed on the cattle runs in the area. At the waterholes may be seen large flocks of ibis and many other birds as well as wild pigs and crocodiles. At times the sky is darkened by flights of flying foxes.

results.creator_credit: Marc Gardiner, Paul Fenech and Hugh Kidd

results.title: Guitar legends: the ultimate anthology
results.brief_description: This disc contains twelve songs from an array of British rock groups, presenting the influence of guitar, and guitarists on popular music, through an array of live performances. The tracks are: Paul Kosso/Free “Alright now”; Andy Powell/Wishbone Ash “Phoenix”; Robin Trower “Night of the guitars”; Ritchie Blackmore/Deep Purple “Improvisation”; Rory Gallagher “Could have had religion”; John Etheridge/Soft Machine “Tale of Taliesin ; Jan Akermann/Focus “Hocus pocus”; Vernon Reed/Jack Bruce “Sunshine of your love”; Steve Hackett “Clocks” ; Steve Howe “Clap”; Mick Box/Uriah Heep “The Magician’s birthday”; Tony Iommi/Black Sabbath “Headless cross”.

results.title: Guitar
results.creator_credit: Barbara Willis Sweete and Niv Fichman
results.brief_description: A vibrant kaleidoscope of Toronto’s International Guitar Festival, “Guitar” meshes dance, mime, visual art and virtuoso performances to create a spectacular and yet intimate celebration of the instrument. For one exciting week the city of Toronto is transformed into the guitar centre of the world. The streets echo with the sounds of the instrument as the great masters from every tradition gather to play for each other - John Williams, Leo Brouwer, Steve Morse to name but a few.
